He later died. The killers, police said, targeted him because he was gay. Congress passed anti-hate crimes legislation bearing his name in 2009. Mickey Schwerner, Andrew Goodman and James Chaney were killed June 21, 1964, following the burning of the church, located, just outside Philadelphia, Miss. The Department of Justice Civil Rights Division reviewed the slayings of the workers and pursued criminal charges. Nine people were convicted. (AP Photo/Rogelio Solis) less Mount Zion Church Fire, 1964 A historic marker outside Mount Zion Church in rural Neshoba County, Mississippi briefly tells of the 1964 deaths of three civil rights workers. The suspect is not yet identified by police. Wilson/San Antonio Express-News Image 14 of 16 San Jose Church Fire, 2014 Deacon Felix Gibson, on Tuesday Jan. 14, 2014, looks through the burned and water damaged items inside the classrooms building at the Greater St. John Baptist Church, which was destroyed by a suspected arsonist in San Jose, Calif. The people of San Jose are on edge after a string of thirteen recent suspicious fires have been set in the early morning hours, burning churches and homes among other buildings. less San Jose Church Fire, 2014 Deacon Felix Gibson, on Tuesday Jan. 14, 2014, looks through the burned and water damaged items inside the classrooms building at the Greater St. John Baptist Church, which was ... more Photo: Michael Macor, The Chronicle Image 15 of 16 Wisconsin Sikh Temple Shooting, 2012 People hold up candles in prayer in front of the Mid Michigan Singh Sabha in Saginaw Township, Mich., Wednesday night, Aug. 15, 2012. Members of the Sikh community held a candlelight vigil, open to the entire community, to honor of the victims of the Wisconsin temple shooting. (AP Photo/The Saginaw News, Jon Garcia) less Wisconsin Sikh Temple Shooting, 2012 People hold up candles in prayer in front of the Mid Michigan Singh Sabha in Saginaw Township, Mich., Wednesday night, Aug. 15, 2012. Members of the Sikh community held a ... more Photo: Jon Garcia, Associated Press Image 16 of 16 Cypress Ranch HS seniors pose with Nazi-style salute 1 / 16 Back to Gallery 
Cypress Ranch High School seniors who displayed a Nazi-style salute in a class photo were reportedly doing it for fun, but not everyone saw it that way. 
According to KPRC , the photo session took place Tuesday, senior picture day for the campus at 10700 Fry Road in Cypress. 
One pose was intended to be serious, with the other light-hearted, which apparently prompted some of the students to raise their hands in a gesture reminiscent of Nazi Germany. 
News coverage of the incident prompted reaction on social media, including a Twitter user who asked President Donald Trump, "What do you have to say to these Cypress Ranch HS students giving heinous Nazi salute in #America?" @realDonaldTrump You could redirect funding from Berkeley to Cypress Ranch High School https://t.co/L53UaUlC3s  https://t.co/fEz5Ze0PHr — Rangi Kemara (@Te_Taipo) February 2, 2017 . @realDonaldTrump POTUS what do you have to say to these Cypress Ranch HS students giving heinous Nazi salute in #America ? #TrumpsAmerica https://t.co/FNl9kBw4Fx — BBombay (@bnb1110) February 2, 2017 
In an email to KPRC, one student said at least 70 or so people were shouting, "Heil Hitler" and "Heil Trump," which that student found "pretty terrifying." 
The school principal, Bob Hull, sent a letter home with students to alert parents about the incident, Cy-Fair Independent School District officials said. 
According to the letter, school officials were investigating the incident and said those implicated would be punished according to the Student Code of Conduct. 
In a statement Thursday, district officials said, "CFISD is extremely disappointed with the actions that were taken by some students at one of our campuses. Please know that we understand the serious nature of the incident and appropriate action has been taken."
